Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Jennifer Walsh is "Combining museum and contemporary data to understand mechanisms of speciation between two tidal marsh birds." The host institution for this fellowship is Cornell University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Irby J. Lovette.

Natural hybrid zones offer the opportunity to investigate evolution in action and the future of biodiversity, while providing insight into the mechanisms driving reproductive isolation between two interacting species. Comparison of temporally replicated data, in particular, provides valuable insight into how a hybrid zone is shifting or expanding in time and space. The fellowship research uses a temporally replicated approach to evaluate patterns in a hybrid zone between two tidal marsh endemics, the Saltmarsh and Nelson's sparrow. This hybrid zone has expanded approximately 160 km in less than a century; however, pure species boundaries appear to be maintained. Temporal comparisons provide new insight into the maintenance of genetically and morphologically pure populations in the face of rapid hybrid zone expansion and is of utmost importance in the northeastern U.S. to local and regional governmental and non-governmental groups concerned with conservation, as Saltmarsh and Nelson's sparrows are both high priority species in this area; the Saltmarsh Sparrow, in particular, is considered globally vulnerable to extinction. The approach combines the use of valuable archived biological collections and cutting edge genomic analyses of extant populations to document the dynamics between Nelson's and Saltmarsh sparrows over the past 125 years. Specimens come from several collections, including Cornell University, Delaware Museum of Natural History, Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology, the University of Connecticut, the University of Maine, and the Canadian Museum of Nature. Given the vulnerability of Nelson's and Saltmarsh sparrows to habitat loss and degradation, a better understanding of temporal dynamics promises to aid the projection of future outcomes in this area as well as general understanding of hybrid zones.

Training goals inchude gaining expertise in population genomics and in newly developed approaches to sequencing partial genomes from archived biological specimens. Educational and public outreach include sharing results of Saltmarsh and Nelson's sparrow interactions with the Saltmarsh Habitat and Avian Research Program, a regional, collaborative tidal-marsh bird monitoring and conservation initiative concerned with management plans for the species, and the very popular interactive websites of the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, e.g., All About Birds and All About Bird Biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hybridization, or the crossing of genetically distinguishable groups of taxa, has long been a topic of interest for biologists. Hybridization occurs frequently in nature and is particularly common in avian systems. Although long considered a detrimental process, there is some indication that introgression and hybridization can be an important mechanism for introducing genetic novelty into a system. Despite advances in genome technology and increased research dedicated to natural hybrid zones, there is a lack of fundamental information on: 1) how hybridization shapes the genomic landscape; 2) how DNA is linked to phenotypic variation within a species; and 3) how patterns of hybridization change over space and time. The goal of this study was to address the above topics by utilizing whole-genome sequencing to analyze spatially and temporally replicated data and to help understand how hybridization shapes patterns of gene exchange in an avian system. This project took advantage of spatially (“pure” populations outside of the hybrid zone and admixed populations inside of the hybrid zone) and temporally (contemporary samples and museum specimens collected 125 years ago) replicated data from two tidal marsh avian endemics –  the saltmarsh (Ammodramus caudacutus) and Nelson’s (A. nelsoni) sparrow. The saltmarsh-Nelson’s sparrow hybrid zone spans a freshwater-saline gradient and is a powerful system for investigating the selective forces shaping hybrid zone dynamics. The abrupt selective gradient characteristic of salt marshes provides unusually tractable opportunities to investigate evolutionary processes, as adaptive challenges posed by the environments are likely strong drivers of selection.

This project was successful in identifying clear changes in the genomic landscape between saltmarsh and Nelson’s sparrows in response to the presence or absence of contemporary gene flow. This work also identified genomic regions that offer compelling candidates for adaptive introgression in this system, building upon a growing body of empirical evidence describing the adaptive role of hybridization in natural hybrid zones. Through this research, underlying genetic mechanisms linked to traits, including bill size and plumage features, were documented. Lastly, this work optimized methodological approaches for combining next generation sequencing technologies with historic specimens. Through these efforts, temporal trends and patterns of hybridization between saltmarsh and Nelson’s sparrows have been identified over a 125-year period.

The project offered extensive postdoctoral training in genomics and bioinformatics, including exposure to cutting edge laboratory and analytical techniques. The work described above has been disseminated to both scientific communities (conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications) and the broader public (public seminars and popular press articles). Lastly, the project allowed for direct mentorship and training in genomic methods of both graduate and undergraduate students by the fellow.
